title: 111_hr1849
content: The Act may be cited as the "World War I Memorial and Centennial Act of 2009". The Act "World War I Memorial and Centennial Act of 2009" acknowledges the significant impact of World War I, with over 4 million Americans serving in defense of liberty, resulting in 375,000 casualties. The events of 1914-1918 shaped the world and the lives of millions, and the centennial provides an opportunity for Americans to learn about their predecessors' sacrifices through commemorative efforts. Kansas City is home to the Liberty Memorial and America's National World War I Museum, seeking to preserve and educate about the history of World War I. The city also houses the national headquarters for the Veterans of Foreign Wars, and is the home state of General John Joseph Pershing, who led the American Expeditionary Forces in Europe during the war. In 1919, Kansas City raised over $2,000,000 in two weeks for a memorial honoring Americans who served in World War I, reflecting public passion about the recently ended war. Following a national architectural competition held by the American Institute of Architects, architect H. Van Buren Magonigle's design was chosen for the Liberty Memorial in Kansas City, Missouri. The dedication of the site on November 1, 1921, was attended by over 100,000 people and marked the only time the five allied military leaders were together in history. General Pershing praised the people of Kansas City for their support during the dedication ceremony. The Liberty Memorial in Kansas City, Missouri was dedicated in honor of the patriotism and sacrifices of those who served in the World War. President Calvin Coolidge initiated a three-year construction project for the memorial in 1924. The 217-foot Liberty Memorial Tower bears an inscription honoring those who defended liberty and the country during the war. The Liberty Memorial in Kansas City, Missouri, dedicated to honoring the sacrifices of World War I veterans, features four stone "Guardian Spirits" symbolizing courage, honor, patriotism, and sacrifice. During a rededication in 1961, former Presidents Truman and Eisenhower recognized the memorial as a reminder of wartime sacrifices and progress. The 106th Congress designated the Liberty Memorial as a national symbol of World War I, and the National World War I Museum in the US is dedicated to the war's history. The National World War I Museum in Kansas City is a renowned center for World War I remembrance. The Liberty Memorial at the National World War I Museum in Kansas City, Missouri is designated as the National World War I Memorial, with no Federal funds allowed for its annual operation or maintenance. The World War I Centennial Commission is established to ensure a suitable observance of the centennial of World War I, promoting values of honor, courage, patriotism, and sacrifice. The Commission's duties include planning and executing programs, encouraging participation from private organizations and governments, and coordinating activities throughout the commemoration. The World War I Centennial Commission is established to coordinate activities related to the centennial of World War I and serve as a clearinghouse for information. Membership consists of 24 members appointed by various leaders. The World War I Centennial Commission consists of 24 members appointed by various leaders, including representatives of the armed services, veterans, Veterans of Foreign Wars, American Legion, Liberty Memorial Association, Archivist of the United States, and Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. The World War I Centennial Commission consists of 24 members appointed by various leaders, including representatives of the armed services, veterans, Veterans of Foreign Wars, American Legion, Liberty Memorial Association, Archivist of the United States, and the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution serving in an ex officio capacity to provide advice and information. Members are appointed for the life of the Commission, must resign if they cease to hold a named position, and all appointments must be made within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The World War I Centennial Commission consists of 24 members appointed by various leaders, including representatives of the armed services, veterans, Veterans of Foreign Wars, American Legion, Liberty Memorial Association, Archivist of the United States, and the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. Members do not receive compensation for their duties and receive travel expenses. A majority of members plus one constitute a quorum, and the Commission elects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson by majority vote. Meetings are held as required. The World War I Centennial Commission appoints a Chairperson who calls meetings, with the first meeting to be held within 120 days. The Commission will meet at America's National World War I Museum in Kansas City, Missouri, and at least once a year thereafter. The Chairperson appoints an executive director and necessary personnel. The executive director and staff of the Commission may be appointed without regard to the provisions of title 5, United States Code, governing appointments in the competitive service, and may be paid without regard to the provisions of chapter 51 and subchapter III of chapter 53 of such title relating to classification and General Schedule pay rates. The rate of pay for the executive director and other staff may not exceed the rate payable for level V of the Executive Schedule under section 5316 of such title. The nonprofit organization administering America's National World War I Museum in Kansas City, Missouri, provides space for the executive director and appointed personnel to work in the museum building. The Commission can hire experts and consultants as needed. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has powers to conduct hearings and sessions. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies. Acceptance of gifts, bequests, and devises is allowed by the Commission. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, or devises for its work. Money and proceeds from sales received shall be deposited in the Treasury for disbursement. The Commission can use the United States mails and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission can receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis to fulfill its responsibilities. It is authorized to procure necessary supplies and services through contracts, leases, or agreements that do not extend beyond its termination date. Additionally, the Commission is required to submit periodic reports to Congress and the President every three months. The Commission is required to submit annual reports on its revenue and expenditures, including gifts over $250, and make specific recommendations for commemorating the centennial of World War I. Additionally, it is granted a waiver from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Commission is authorized $500,000 annually for fiscal years 2010-2019. The Inspector General of the Department of the Interior conducts an annual audit and reports findings to relevant committees. The Commission on Government Reform will terminate either 30 days after World War I centennial activities or on July 28, 2019. This section will be effective starting January 1, 2010. Passed the House of Representatives on November 5, 2009.
